description: As of March 16, the government of Latvia announced that preschools and childcare facilities will only be available for children whose parents may prove that the child and family have not been abroad and have not been in contact with Covid-19 patients or their contacts during the last 14 days. description: On April 30th Latvia decided to cancel 9th grader exams for this school year and reduce number of exams for 12th school grade. UPDATE: On April 30th Lativa decided to keep schools closed. All state tests for 9th graders in Latvia have been cancelled for this school year. The number of compulsory tests for 12th graders has been reduced. Now compulsory exams include only one foreign language exam, Latvian language exam and mathematics exam.

description: Latvia limits time for culture, entertainment, outdoor sports and other recreational activities from 8:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.

Latvia limits time for culture, entertainment, outdoor sports and other recreational activities from 8:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. UPDATE: The original restriction of working hours of leisure and entertainment venues, including restaurants, was from 8.00 to 22.00. Now they will be able to open from 07:00 until midnight.

On 29 December 2020, the government of Latvia introduced a curfew for New Year's holidays and weekend from December 30 until January 4, and the weekend following Orthodox Christmas on January 8 and 9, during which individuals must stay at their place of residence between 22:00 and 5:00 except for emergencies and work-related matters
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On September 11, the government of Latvia restricted travelers from Estonia. The government will require travelers coming from Estonia to self-quarantine for two weeks, granting an exception to truck drivers, diplomats and others who need to cross the border for work to skip the self-quarantine with proof of employment.

description: Latvia government stated on 29th March: For the purposes of conducting an epidemiological investigation and verifying the veracity of information on movement provided by a person and upon the request of the Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, the State Police will have the right to request information from electronic communications operators on specific persons who may have a status of the infected person or contact person.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From July 16, the government of Latvia announced all passengers of international transport will have to submit a completed questionnaire to the carrier before entering Latvia, indicating the countries visited during the last 14 days, contact information and chosen address where the two-week self-isolation period is planned. Information on passengers who have been in Covid-19-affected countries will be passed on to the National Police for self-isolation control and the Center for Disease Prevention and Control to identify possible contact persons promptly if necessary.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: As of July 28, the Ministry of Health of Latvia require guest workers from countries with high COVID-19 risk to be tested for the infection before starting work, specifically five to seven days after arrival in Latvia. description:
Latvian Finance Minister Jānis Reirs’ initiated a work group for support of entrepreneurship and the employed on Wednesday. At 1 April they decided to finance efforts to battle consequences from COVID-19 from the state budget. The work group ordered Economy Ministry to develop an economic recovery plan.
Later EU funds might be needed, Finance Ministry work group will review proposals on distribution of funding from EU funds.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 13, Latvia (Prime Minister + Finance Minister + Central Bank Governor) announces financial instruments (a billion-euro fund) to assist businesses via the state-owned ALTUM development bank. Possible measures are e.g.: tax holidays, paying for sick leave, import and export guarantees
type_text: Economic / financial policy to cope with potential economic crisis in relation with the pandemic crisis

description: Latvia recommends to cancel all unneccessary travel abroad

description:
Latvia closes all non essential businesses from March 13. This includes: 
Nightclubs, entertainment centres, fitness clubs. Some restaurants and bars are open (e.g. take away). Shopping malls are closed. Exceptions are: food shops, press kiosks, pharmacies (incl. veterinary pharmacies), vaccination cabinets, opticians, pet food, dry cleaners, hygiene and household stores, building and garden supply stores.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down

description:
As of June 9, the government of Latvia issued rules and restrictions for the food service industry to continue operations, including requiring table disinfection after each visitor's meal, having no more than 4 visitors who are not members of the same household indoors at one table, 
having no more than 8 visitors who are not members of the same household at one table outdoors,  distance of two meters between the tables is observed, if there is no partition wall between them, and hours between 6:30-2:00.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 12 Latvian Prime Minister Krišjānis Kariņš declared that starting from March 13 large public gatherings of more than 200 people will be banned and smaller gatherings should be cancelled or postponed if at all possible.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Latvia bans organised public events. All other gatherings may not exceed 50 participants from March 14. All events have to end by 11pm

On march 29th Latvian government declared that all meetings are prohibited - except for the holding of funeral ceremonies outdoors, which will be subject to a two-meter inter-personal distance.

Any public events, as well as meetings, marches and pickets are prohibited. Indoor sports and religious activities are also prohibited.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Lavtiva bans large public gatherins with over 200 people from 13 March

Latvia bans large public gatherings with over 200 people from 13 March. Updates to this policy added further restrictions to the number of people, but as of 12 May the country is allowing public gatherings of up to 25 people. UPDATE: The original severe restrictions on public gatherings, starting 13 March, are being relaxed to allow for public gatherings of up to 25 people starting 12 May.

As of May 12, the government of Latvia allowed non-contact sports training and lessons to occur in-person with the stipulation that indoor training may not exceed three hours. There is no limit for outdoor sessions.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of May 12, the government of Latvia allowed non-contact sports to begin lessons and training with the stipulation that no more than 25 people gather in one training group at the same time.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting June 9, the government of Latvia requires public markets and food places to provide at least 4m^2 of space indoors per visitor. Larger social gatherings will be permitted. Up to 100 people can gather indoors, but up to 300 people outdoors, provided they keep a distance of two meters apart.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting June 9, the government of Latvia requires public markets and food places to provide at least 4m^2 of space indoors per visitor. From July 1, restaurants must provide 3 m^2 of space per visitor. UPDATE: The original policy requires public markets and food places to provide at least 4m^2 of space indoors per visitor. The new policy requires public markets and food places to provide 3 m^2 of space per visitor.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From July 1 until July 31, the government of Latvia will allow events with up to 500 people in larger indoor spaces.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From July 1 to July 31, the government of Latvia will allow no more than 1000 people to gather outside.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of Saturday, July 11, until September Latvian government has declared that a maximum of four guests who are not members of the same household may be present at an indoor table and a maximum of eight guests who are not members of the same household may be present at an outdoor table.
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting August 1, the government of Latvia will allow as many as 3,000 people to gather outside, provided that the epidemiological situation in the country does not deteriorate.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting from August 17, the government of Latvia will allow up to 1,000 people to gather indoors.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From Wednesday, October 14, the Latvian government declared that private events will be limited to a maximum of 30 people inside and 300 outside.
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 24, the Latvian government has decided that a maximum of 10 people may be on the premises at private event venues indoors and a maximum of 100 people outdoors. A maximum of 300 people will be allowed to gather indoors at public events.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On november 6th Latvian government declared new restrictions: no more than 10 people from no more than two households can gather at private events at the same time. Up to 50 people can gather outside for meetings, processions and pickets. More than two households can attend a funeral, up to a maximum of 10 people (excluding funeral staff).
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 14 March, Latvia's prime minister announced that only groups of two people or families can gather at once in public places during state of emergency period, and that a 2-meter minimum distance must be maintained from other people.

On March 31 the Latvian government put a ban on people who have come to Latvia from abroad from using public transportation, having guests and going to meetings. 

The penalty for non-compliance with compulsory emergency epidemiological requirements will be up to EUR 2,000 for natural persons and up to EUR 5,000 for legal entities.
Use of face covers became mandatory in public transport on 7 October, declares Latvian Government.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From november 9, new restrictions take place in Latvia: hairdressing services are available by prior appointment and with a distance of 2 meters between clients, tattoo parlors must close, retail outlets must provide 10 square meters per visitor and masks must be worn and masks should also be worn in open market areas and street sales.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all indoor spaces
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
